marketNews.title: Indonesia Economy +5.12% YoY in 2Q25, Above Expectations
marketNews.content:
The Central Statistics Agency (BPS) reported that Indonesia's economy grew by 5.12 percent year-on-year in the second quarter of 2025, compared with 5.05 percent YoY in 2Q24 and 4.87 percent YoY in 1Q25, surpassing the consensus forecast of 4.8 percent YoY. This result brings the 1H25 year-on-year growth to 4.99 percent. As context, the government is targeting a 5 percent YoY growth level based on the 2025 state budget, which has been downgraded, while Bank Indonesia’s 2025 target – also downgraded twice – is in the range of 4.6-5.4 percent YoY. On a quarterly basis, the economy expanded by 4.04 percent quarter-on-quarter, higher than the consensus estimate of 3.7 percent QoQ (versus -0.98 percent QoQ in 1Q25 and 3.79 percent QoQ in 2Q24).

On the expenditure side, the 2Q25 annual growth was driven by gross fixed capital formation (PMTB) / investment, which rose 6.99 percent YoY (versus 4.42 percent YoY in 2Q24 and 2.12 percent YoY in 1Q25), propelled by a 30.37 percent YoY increase in government capital spending. Household consumption grew 4.97 percent YoY (versus 4.93 percent YoY in 2Q24 and 4.95 percent YoY in 1Q25) as primary-goods spending and mobility improved.

By industry, the manufacturing sector contributed the most to growth, increasing 5.68 percent YoY (versus 3.95 percent YoY in 2Q24 and 4.55 percent YoY in 1Q25) and accounting for 1.13 percentage points of the total (versus 0.79 pp in 2Q24 and 0.93 pp in 1Q25), driven by palm-oil, iron and steel products. Other services (+11.31 percent YoY) and corporate services (+9.31 percent YoY) were the fastest-growing segments in 2Q25, supported by higher visitor numbers at recreational sites and increased activity by travel agencies and tour operators.

Geographically, Sulawesi (+5.83 percent YoY) and Java (+5.24 percent YoY) recorded the highest growth rates. Sumatra (+4.96 percent YoY), Kalimantan (+4.95 percent YoY), Bali & Nusa Tenggara (+3.73 percent YoY), and Maluku & Papua (+3.33 percent YoY) posted lower growth than the national average.

Key Takeaway: We assess that 2H25 growth will depend on (1) the impact of the United States tariff that will start to apply in August 2025, (2) acceleration of government spending, and (3) the trend of declining interest rates. Investors should also monitor the presidential speech scheduled for Friday, 15 August, which may highlight priority programs for 2026.

marketNews.title: Other Hot Topics You Need to Know
marketNews.content:
1. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani issued Minister of Finance Regulation No.55/2025 concerning the mechanism for providing interest-rate subsidies or margin subsidies for dense-labour-intensive industrial credit, aimed at increasing the competitiveness capacity of businesses and expanding labor absorption. Under the regulation, the government will grant a 5 percent effective annual subsidy on interest rates and margins for dense-labour-intensive industrial credit, although the rate may be adjusted by the Policy Committee established by the President. Eligible recipients are individuals or enterprises classified under specific dense-labour-intensive industry categories, with the detailed categories and eligibility criteria to be defined by the Ministry of Industry.

2. A Reuters survey showed that India recorded a 10 percent month-on-month decline in palm-oil imports to 858,000 tonnes in July 2025, after reaching an 11-month high in June 2025. The drop was influenced by order cancellations by Indian refiners as palm-oil futures prices rose on the Malaysia exchange in July 2025.

3. Astra Financial reported total transactions of IDR 2.4 trillion over the 11-day period of the Gaikindo Indonesia International Auto Show (GIIAS) 2025, surpassing its target of IDR 2.2 trillion (111.5 percent of target) and stemming from 6,406 vehicle order letters (SPK).

4. Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Bahlil Lahadalia announced that the government will build solar power plants with a total capacity of up to 100 gigawatts to meet the energy needs of the Red-White Village Cooperatives (KDMP). The projects will be implemented in phases, with battery components planned to be fully sourced domestically. Separately, Coordinating Minister for Food Affairs Zulkifli Hasan indicated that the investment value of the project could reach USD 100 billion, and related regulations for village solar projects will be finalized soon.

marketNews.title: Danger of Overconfidence in Investment Decision Making
marketNews.content: "OVER CONFIDENT in stocks will kill you." – teddyed

tickerNews.title: EMTK Increases Direct Ownership in SCMA to 66.11% after Purchasing Approximately 325 Million Shares
tickerNews.content: Elang Mahkota Teknologi (EMTK) bought roughly 325 million shares of Surya Citra Media (SCMA) at an average price of about IDR 210.6 per share between 28 July and 4 August 2025. The total transaction value was approximately IDR 68.4 billion. After this transaction, EMTK’s direct ownership stake in SCMA rose from 65.67 percent to 66.11 percent.

tickerNews.title: Telkom Indonesia Revises 2025 Revenue Growth Target to Flat and Lowers EBITDA Margin Guidance
tickerNews.content: During the 2Q25 earnings call on Tuesday, 5 August, Telkom Indonesia management said the company revised its 2025 revenue growth target from low single-digit to flat. The company also lowered its 2025 EBITDA margin guidance from a range of 50-52 percent to approximately 50 percent.

tickerNews.title: PTPS Announces Interim Dividend of IDR 6.5 Billion (IDR 3 per Share) for FY 2025
tickerNews.content: Pulau Subur (PTPS) plans to distribute an interim dividend for fiscal year 2025 amounting to approximately IDR 6.5 billion, or IDR 3 per share, implying a dividend yield of about 2.1 percent. The cum-date in the regular market is 13 August 2025, with payment scheduled for 27 August 2025.

tickerNews.title: ACES Reports 2Q25 Net Profit of IDR 151 Billion, Down 6% YoY, and 1H25 Net Profit of IDR 292 Billion
tickerNews.content: Aspirasi Hidup Indonesia (ACES) recorded a net profit of IDR 151 billion in 2Q25, down 6 percent YoY but up 7 percent QoQ. The 1H25 net profit totaled IDR 292 billion, a 20 percent YoY decline, representing 33 percent of the 2025 consensus estimate (versus about 39 percent over the prior three years). The profit drop was driven by a lower gross profit margin of 46.7 percent (down from 48.6 percent in 2Q24 and 48 percent in 1Q25), the lowest since 4Q18 (46.5 percent). Operating profit fell 7 percent YoY in 2Q25, resulting in 1H25 operating profit of IDR 385 billion, a 19 percent YoY decline and below the 36 percent consensus estimate. Revenue was flat in 2Q25 (0 percent YoY, 0 percent QoQ), leading to 1H25 revenue growth of 3 percent YoY, in line with the 47 percent consensus estimate but below the management guidance of 5 percent YoY revenue growth for 2025.

tickerNews.title: RAJA Plans LNG Infrastructure Acquisition and Reports 1H25 Capex of USD 20 Million (29% of 2025 Allocation)
tickerNews.content: President Director Djauhar Maulidi of Raja announced that the company's plan to acquire an LNG infrastructure firm is expected to be completed in 3Q25. He also mentioned a downstream acquisition under due diligence, anticipated to be finalized by the end of 2025. Raja recorded capex of USD 20 million during 1H25, representing 29 percent of the total 2025 capex allocation. The capex is focused on strategic projects such as building a compressor in Sengkang, South Sulawesi, constructing the Tanjung Batu-Samarinda fuel pipeline, and developing pipelines in West Java.
